content:
I think you need to check the account settings for the authentication method to be used. Note: Yahoo Microsoft (MSN,hotmail, live and outlook) and Gmail all require oauth authentication, in those instances there is no "password" only an oauth line in the password manager that contains a "token" issued by your provider in the initial authentication process. It is not your password. Although if deleted, or denied by your provider (lie they forced a new password on you) it should initiate a new authentication web page flow. I have seen these pages variously described a a bug, a nag screen and one person thought they had been hacked. Many simply ignore them and then complain about non receipt of mail.

So what authentication method are you using and what mail provider are you using it with?
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I doubt there is a solution. Thunderbird simply passes the link to the operating system to open using the default browser. So there is little if anything Thunderbird knows. YOu have more control on Linux, but windows it is the operating system all the way.

Check out the registry edit in this link https://superuser.com/questions/166479/force-chrome-to-open-new-pages-in-new-window-not-tab-when-opened-from-a-progr That should work as it modifies the command line used by chrome to force a new windows for the link.

content:
When I had duel-boot I had problems if the system I wasn't using had only been hibernated rather than fully closed down.

There could also be problems with Linux and Windows not using the same systems for ownership and other attributes. For instance Linux doesn't have an Archive attribute and Windows doesn't have an Executable one.

content:
For the second point, TB is supposed to underline the top message in a thread that has new messages. But there is a way to bold the top message in a thread with unread messages:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1442668#answer-1642934

Search Messages appears under Edit/Find, probably because the Find options in Firefox are also under Edit. But in TB, Search Messages is also under Tools in the 3-bar AppMenu, which makes more sense.

content: The bug, in my opinion, is showing them at all in favorites. I say this because unified folder aren't folders but a virtual collection of folders. My suggestion is to include both favorite folders and unified folders for the same result.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
The bug, in my opinion, is showing them at all in favorites. I say this because unified folder aren't folders but a virtual collection of folders. My suggestion is to include both favorite folders and unified folders for the same result.

Thanks for the reply. I was worried someone might say this.

When I use the unified folders tab as a whole though it also includes many other unified folders I do not need to see.

Is there a way to hide them?

After a lot of puzzling, I found a way to display only show the unified folders I want to see, by adding this code to userChrome.css:

/* Selects all of the top-level tabs of the unified folders inbox and hides them */ .sidebar-panel-scroll .unselectable:nth-child(1) > ul > li { 

   display: none;

}

/* Selects the specific folders to display */ .sidebar-panel-scroll .unselectable:nth-child(1) li[title^="Inbox"], .sidebar-panel-scroll .unselectable:nth-child(1) li[title^="Drafts"], .sidebar-panel-scroll .unselectable:nth-child(1) li[title^="Sent"] { 

   display: list-item;

}

But it's a rather complex workaround üòÖ I think it'd be nicer to have the option to add unified inboxes to favorites (and to keep them there!). Cause if they're not supposed to be there, it's a bug that they do appear there.

Looks like this:
creator: michelklaasen0

content:
I found a work around, for anyone interested.

In the menu, under File > New > Saved Search, you can create a new Saved Search, which acts pretty much as a virtual inbox. I selected all my inboxes, put it under Local Folders, and then I can favorite it and it works just like what I had in mind.

Thunderbird really has a lot of functionality üòÑ
creator: michelklaasen0

creator: @next

content:
1. The setting in Thunderbird to allow antivirus to quarantine messages has nothing to do with this. It writes all new mail to the temp folder so antivirus product that do not scan email can have at it. Nothing more. So having it off is actually standard as there are few except defender that do not scan email. But that is also a large part of why I use defender. No pesky email scanner.

Personally I am guessing bit defender has quarantined or deleted you mail store. They work through Identifying a "threat" and asking you to authorized an automatic fix. Often this is the deletion of 20 years worth of email stored in that mail folder. This is why I exclude antivirus products from scanning my profile folder. There is no such thing a a "threat" in a stored email. Thunderbird does not execute scripts in the email and attachments are stored a mime encoded plain text so email in storage is not a threat. Even attachments pose on threat until they are decrypted and turned back into a file, and that occurs in the system temp folder where the antivirus already has access to kill the file. So I suggest you establish of bitdefender has deleted something imporant and how the bitdefender folks propose to recover your data if it has.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I really love it when folk pay for support from multiple other providers and then trot in here where it is peer support and complain about the support.

So lets look at your issues

1. This is peer support. No one gets paid and no one is going to fix anything for you. You will get information which you can act on, but only after you actually provided information that might offer someone enough to start a support process. You have posted a topic here, then replied to it almost immediately, thus you have removed your topic from the new awaiting answers list. I found it by accident.

2. No one is going to be ringing you. That is something that Mozilla specifically prohibits. Hence folk have their email addresses and phone numbers removed from their posts in this public forum, as has occurred with yours.

3. All you have offered is "All of my folders are gone in my email." and you apparently expect someone to figure out what you did and what sequence of events led to this happening. More information is required, much more information.

Folders in IMAP mail account (which I am assuming you are using, but again a guess because you do not say) routinely fail to appear after connection to the mail server is lost ie they synchronize into oblivion. They will usually reappear when there is a connection to the mail server so they can synchronize again.

But have you been seeing any form of error messages. About connections or timeouts or passwords perhaps? Did Thunderbird just update? What antivirus are you using? What email provider are you getting mail from?

The Domain cssiservices.com appears to be using outlook.com MX servers https://intodns.com/cssiservices.com Microsoft have recently been enforcing new authentication standards, specifically oauth (which they call modern authentication) have you made the change? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/microsoft-oauth-authentication-and-thunderbird-202
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Therein lies the problem. The account name is independent of the email address. There is no account with the full email address. I don't believe that Thunderbird is trying to connect with the account name. How can I see what it is using?

content: The account name in Thunderbird is just documentation for the user. Thunderbird does not use it except to identify the account from other accounts. The server needs the email address to confirm to the email host that you are a legitimate user. Until you enter the full email address, you will not connect.
